review_title: Great mission and people, lots of potential, rampant poor management
job_title: Currently Seeking Employment in Los Angeles, CA
pros: There are a lot of benefits to working at Jumpstart, most notably an important mission and great, hardworking people. They offer generous paid vacation time, and sick time in addition to paid holiday time. Jumpstart touts exciting core values like social justice and inclusive leadership among others and is doing important internal DEI work. Jumpstart has done good work and has the potential to do even more.
cons: Many staff are overworked and underpaid for their time, dedication, and expertise. Jumpstart's structure is top-heavy with too many leadership positions. There is poor management training and accountatbility across many departments and not enough investment, financial or otherwise, in generating new positions, systems, and processes to support people "on the ground."

review_title: A great place to begin an education career!
job_title: Jumpstart Corps Member in Berkeley, CA
pros: I was fortunate to work with an excellent team of fellow UC Berkeley students at a preschool in Oakland. Our experiences were challenging, yet very rewarding. The preschool staff welcomed us and we really felt like our efforts were an important part of the school. The training was rigorous, but well thought-out and executed. I never felt as if they wasted our time with any mandatory meetings. We learned teaching techniques, types of difficulties some students may have and how to better work with those children. We also discussed the opportunity gap more thoroughly and how socio-economic challenges effect the neighborhoods that we served. Each lesson plan was cohesive and centrally themed on what goals we had for the week and the corresponding story that activities were based on, each gradually building on one another. We were encouraged to be creative and make props or project ideas to include in lesson plans. We also reached out to the community with projects that involved the students and their parents. It was a great opportunity to gain some excellent training and actually work one-on-one with students.
cons: It's not always easy working in an under-served school. The preschool wasn't in the safest neighborhood and your students deal with a range of challenges from unstable homes to learning difficulties. That's quite a lot for a college student to take on, but it does prepare you for life outside of school - an eye opener to what the education world is like.

pros: Great for college students who want to gain experience in teaching.

pros: Work with amazing college students committed to early childhood education. Other site managers  are great and will be your support network. Unfortunately, relationships will be remote/virtual.
cons:
Salary is not competitive compared to other non profits doing similar work
Mismanagement of finances - I have little faith in the leaders controlling the purse strings or raising the money
Lack of professional development and upward trajectory for  site managers means you'll likely be pushed out before receiving a promotion and their "promotions" are usually in name only. i.e. there's no financial difference between being a Senior Site Manager and a Site Manager.

pros: The experience of working online is amazing and is much easier remotely.
cons: Need to be able to manage time well.

review_title: Unrealistic expectations. Little to No Support.
pros: A worthy cause if we had the capacity to execute
cons:
There are serious staffing shortages. The workload is redistributed amongst its existing staff. We have no choice but to accept the absurd demands because everyone else is doing it too. It’s normal here. 

We get encouraging reminders for the many things they need us to do in a short amount of time. Jumpstart knows that we care deeply about our students and the mission. They remind us how the excessive workload is in the name of “serving the children.”

That’s all fine and dandy but will you be paying us for our 12 hour work days? Is it fair to ask someone to work unfair conditions because they care about your organization?

Do you care about the children  and the cause enough to support your staff to get this work done in an ethical and fair way? 

Do you care about the children and the cause enough to notice that passionate and dedicated staff are leaving in droves because of these conditions? 

It’s obvious we care about the children and cause. It is not right to use this as a tool to propagate unfair work standards.

We are not oblivious to the fact that the support staffing is reduced every year and the work remaining is silently tacked onto our growing list of responsibilities. 

Do you understand why there is backlash from institutions we parter with?

pros: lots of training on working with kids
cons: traveled far to schools. they were not close to our office

pros: Important mission that addresses marginalized community need; rewarding to support volunteers (Corps members) with leadership/professional development; opportunities to work both at the university and community as you cultivate relationships with program partners, corps members, university staff, other Jumpstart staff; effective model when the right support exists to implement high-quality program
cons: The Site Manager position is the programmatic position most responsible for supporting day-to-day implementation of the Jumpstart program, but it requires an unrealistically wide breadth of work with often inadequate technical support from Jumpstart; pay was not aligned with amount of work, was not adjusted based on cost of living, and is inconsistent across sites; inconsistency in terms of prioritizing/supporting Site Managers with professional development; lack of diversity (majority of staff in management positions are white cis-women) and occasional culturally insensitive marketing (internally and externally) despite the majority of targeted population being POC

pros: Rewarding experience working with children.

job_title: Team Leader in New York, NY
pros: Great experience, wonderful leadership, definitely recommend.

pros: All the site managers and program directors are really great to work with! Jumpstart really cares about its mission, and everyone is treated like a community. Jumpstart really emphasizes work-life balance, which is great (although kind of impossible during many parts of the year) and everyone getting to know each other on a personal level.
cons: I don't think site managers are appreciated by many on the national level who are making decisions. We're working 12 hour days to make sure Corp members are equipped to go into the classroom, our sites are in compliance, etc. and many outside of our immediate supervisors don't realize the amount of work we do. This leads to a lack of support on some levels. This is starting to change, but I think ultimately, something needs to change regarding the work load for site managers if they want to start keeping people for longer than a year or two. Also, it often seems like Jumpstart is so focused on expanding as fast as possible, poor decisions are being made -decisions that impact the quality of the service we provide children and site managers' ability to do their job well.

review_title: Do not confuse Corps Members (paid volunteers) with actual employees
pros: Corps members (paid volunteers) love Jumpstart.  It's a great way to gain ECE experience and work with kids.  The work they do with under-served children is invaluable. As a staff member, the benefits were great and the salary was fair.  I would have worked for Jumpstart for a very long time if it had not been driven into the ground by poor decisions and an incompetent CEO.
cons: Two massive layoffs in 2 years and constantly shifting priorities, duties, staff, and supervisors make for a very stressful work environment.  Each year the funding is less and less.  Every 9 months, employees have to wonder if their position/site will be funded for the next year.  Supervisors either dodge working at all or control all information to give themselves a sense of importance and job security. This is not that way organizations should be run.

pros:
Jumpstart targets a very legitimate societal shortfall, the achievement gap. It argues, perhaps persuasively, that the best way to change this in the long term is to ensure all children have the chance to succeed in school. To achieve this they provide direct service, advocate, and raise awareness.

It's a laudible goal and for the most part the people that work there are great.
cons:
The crew that comprises the executive team lives in a delusional bubble that all things are well and they are the best thing for Jumpstart. Meanwhile the organization has devolved into petty infighting, bitterness and resentment. There's a major cultural problem that's simply going unaddressed. Meanwhile the directors and executives get promoted and pat themselves on the back.

Jumpstart will lowball your starting salary and only give you a pittance for raises. Your advancement opportunities depend on your working for one of the executives and getting on the fast track of ass kissing. If you succeed you will get raises and promotions twice a year and quickly outpace your peers.

I would not recommend people to apply here unless they wanted a case study in how good intentions can go awry.

pros: Jumpstart is very passionate about its mission, and works hard to get its employees to understand buy, into, and take part in creating and implementing its mission-driven strategic plans. It takes its work seriously, but also has a fun, optimistic atmosphere.
cons: Although Jumpstart wants to create a democratic atmosphere, it hasn't been successful in creating solid communication between the National Office and its Regional Offices. When I was with Jumpstart, there was definitely this sense of animosity towards the National Office, even though it was clear that they meant well. The economic downturn resulted in a lot of people being let go, and Senior Management was not successful in ensuring this happened smoothly. I think at Jumpstart a lot of great ideas get put on the table, but they just don't get communicated or implemented well. Someone needs to supervise the quality of the trickle-down.

pros:
- Learning how to teach children not only to read, but to be good to one another, how to share, how to listen to another's feelings and how to be a good friend
- The pay is decent for a college student, and you get a raise each year
- Valuable experience that you can apply to any career; it teaches you communication skills (you communicate not only with children, but with the manager and site manager, head teachers, parents and family members), lesson plan writing skills, activities development skills, organizational skills, the list goes on
- Friendship (sometimes the other Corps Members become your close friends)
cons: The only con is having to meet on Saturdays or sometimes Sundays for training. But the training is invaluable. The information that you learn in those sessions stick with you for the rest of your occupational life and  you can carry what you learned to any career you choose.

pros: Working with Students, children, and teachers
cons:
Along with asking students to backdate forms and lie about dates to account for Jumpstart’s lack of internal systems -this is a whole other issue- we also 
ask them to work for free at some sites.  
Somehow, Jumpstart has convinced some major institutions that asking struggling undergrads to work for free is the way to go. Go Jumpstart!

I’m extremely disappointed with this program. They are really missing the mark here. If you want to break cycles of poverty, this is completely wrong. You can’t ask work-study students to volunteer to dodge paying work-study fees. Just because you can, doesn’t mean you should. You are asking students to take up more debt or find other jobs to pay for their Jumpstart service.... YOU are perpetuating the cycles of poverty.  

What were you thinking when you came up with the idea to ask financially strapped students to work without pay and then normalizing this?

This is why the teacher shortages exist.  

Jumpstart’s practices are mind blowing and counterintuitive to the mission. The systems are truly a mess. People are noticing and non-student staff turn-over rate shows it.

review_title: Management lacks competence, work environment is tense and cut-throat, but working with the community can be meaningful.
pros:
Meaningful work.
Other braches throughout US are friendly and efficient.
cons:
Those in management compensate for their incompentence/laziness by putting it on others and then blaming them, especially new staff.
New staff receive little training for such a complex organization. Must scavenge for little scraps of knowledge that people will be willing to give up here and there.
No one willing to take on extra responsibility of helping/training new staff.
Competitive and tense work environment due to women-dominated "catty" staff.
Work/life balance not encouraged in SF office due to management encouraging workhorse atmosphere and not encouraging team environment. Also, not willing to spend money on staff outside of pizza lunches once in a while.

pros: Great Experience to help children learn and better their futures.  Working in the city of Boston was a great way feel like a part of the city and have a sense of community.  It was also very important to see the problems the city is facing and how we as citizens can help make it better.  There are also plenty of job opportunities and connections that can be found within the Jumpstart Alumni network that make it easy to find people working in any field from education to even finance.
cons: It is a decent amount of hours for a college student (the programs aim).  If you do not complete your hours there are harsh penalties, to harsh for volunteerism in some peoples opinions and justifiable in others.  Going to different parts of the city costs time and money and the organization does not provide any compensation for it.

pros: -Great mission that provides college students with a chance to engage with preschool children and their families
cons:
-Organization views communities of color and educators in low-income neighborhoods with a deficit perspective 
-Curriculum is NOT research-based; it does not take into account individual children's interests and repeats the same curriculum annually
-Site staff is paid poorly and often below what other entry-level positions on a university campus are paid. For site staff, work expectations exceed pay for a non-profit organization; executive team, however, is paid very well
-Pay for college students is abysmal. Often requires college volunteers (many of whom are on financial aid) to work a second job to supplement their earnings

job_title: Jumpstart Corps Member in UC Berkeley, CA
pros: The interview process was very quick. I submitted my application, was called for an interview, then had a Skype interview, and was hired. The entire process took around 2 weeks. Jumpstart's mission is so important, and being able to be a part of closing the achievement gap is really rewarding. You can advance quickly here, and Jumpstart will open many doors down the line.
cons: The main problem I have is with the pay. The salary caps at $3,000, even if you're a work study student and your amount is more than that. If you really need a job for financial reasons, Jumpstart may not be for you.

pros: Jumpstart is a great organization that is committed to children and the education gap across America. Jumpstart seeks to stay on the cusp of development and maintain a leader in the early education sphere. Jumpstart provides trainings for the mentors to delve into the program in an intentional way.
cons: Jumpstart operates across the nation and lacks the ability to support it's staff from a geographical and social standpoint. At times restructuring has caused layoffs without a plan for retaining the staff and expertise. Demands placed on staff can be unobtainable.

review_title: Good intentions, not so great execution
pros: Great program that offers opportunities to help narrow the achievement gap before children can even fall behind. Friendly staff and lots of joy. Everyone working here demonstrates a passion for the mission and values that Jumpstart strives for.
cons:
Low pay that is inequitable, especially if you are not one of the mostly young white women fresh out of college who have roommates and are supported by their parents that work here. This is a major factor in turn over, especially for the staff that do not fit this mold. Those that do fit the mold also leave as soon as they finish grad school, get married, take on any new responsibilities, or grow in any other way. 

White savior mentality abound. Many staff members  join the organization with good intentions but no real connection or relationship with the communities they work in. Their allyship is often performative at best. Though I truly believe the communities and school they work with benefit tremendously from the program, their lack of understanding can also widen the gap between them and those communities. They are paternalistic to those they serve and exhibit subtle (and not-so-subtle) racist attitudes like clutching their purses if a black man gets on the elevator with them or talking to the few minorities in  the office about the voluntourism they did in that person's native country. This diminishes the number of minorities willing to work at HQ and also pushes away volunteers from those communities because they can feel staff pitying/looking down at them and their people.

review_title: They hire talented people just to tear them to pieces
pros:
Work is meaning...for the first year
Except to the agency you work for, you are very loved and valued in the community
cons:
-Lack solid professional growth
-HR admitted that they don't want to label employee's actual job with terms that's easily understood by other professionals of similar fields, or else the agency will lose their staff.  But the agency also doesn't invest in training that will help employees gain skills to help them improve their work either.
-Never reward or fire people for their performance.  I mean never!

job_title: Corps Member in Queens Village, NY
pros: Great people you are placed to work with. I enjoyed working with pre-k students. They enjoy learning so much and you get to make it fun for them. I had the opportunity to as work alongside the classroom teacher and she let me teach lessons on my own which was really cool.
cons: If you decide to do this please remember to keep an open mind and to come with patience. You are one of these kids first teachers so many of them will struggle. Also most of these students come from low income areas which means that they will have hardships that can be visible and will need your help copping with.

review_title: Best paying job for college student. Great first job!
pros: The work is very important. Increasing literacy among the poorest children is very fulfilling. As volunteer coordinator my mission was to communicate the mission of Jumpstart to the community and get non-employees involved in the classroom work of Jumpstart.
cons: As volunteer coordinator I was responsible for maintaining databases with contact information of volunteers. This work was very tedious. Also, there are periodic conference calls with senior management at the regional office-I found these painful too.

job_title: Jumpstart Corps Member in Chicago, IL
pros: If you get a good classroom, and a good team, the job will be a lot of fun.  A lot of hands on experience with the public school system and with the preschoolers.  Definitely a part time job though.  Very few opportunities for significant advancement.
cons: Jumpstart definitely feels corporate, and a lot of mandates come from higher up.  So there isn't as much freedom, flexibility, and autonomy as other jobs I have had.

pros: The kids. Almost all of the smart, idealistic staff.
cons: I worked at Jumpstart from 2008-2011. At that time the board had named an operations guy to be CEO, and he proved unsuited to the role. Upon joining, I watched him destroy several highly creative directors and managers who didn't fit his notion of process-above-all. I gave him credit for trying to self-correct, but he was simply too abrasive in approach and corrosive to morale. Since leaving, I have seen the organization flail about with a succession of leaders who all tried their best...but failed. It seems to continue even today. I wish it were not so, because the core mission is truly great.

review_title: Not only fun, but great opportunity for professional development
pros: Working at Jumpstart has allowed me to work with great people towards a common goal, while gaining invaluable skills in project management, leadership, and education.
cons: It's really hard working with both your peers and preschoolers. There is a steep learning curve that can often be stressful.

job_title: Corps Member in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Connecting and building relationships with the children was very rewarding. I learned a lot for my future career as a teacher, such as patience, time management, and behavior management. The kids will love you when you invest time in them.
cons: It is very time consuming but mostly energy consuming. Kids have a lot of energy and at times balancing another job or school can be very challenging.

pros: Company offered great training and support. The work was rewarding and you build awesome relationships with kids and team. Definitely a gratifying and growing experience.
cons: You are somewhat limited to the material that is offered by the program. This can sometimes get repetitive and you'll have a hard time engaging the students. As a team leader you are responsible for motivating and guiding your team, confronting a number of egotistical issues.

job_title: Jumpstart Corps Member in Washington, DC
pros: Jumpstart provides great support. They get you ready for your classroom sessions with plenty of training and provided lesson plans to follow. Great way to get into a preschool classroom and work with kids. Also you learn about developmental literacy.
cons: If you enjoy working with small kids then there are few cons. Still the work is tiring and requires a lot of energy. Many are doing it as a part time job while in school so it takes a large chunk of time and can be exhausting. Travel time is not compensated and can take a long time depending on location

review_title: great opportunity to work with kids
pros: Working closely with young children is fun and a great learning experience. The kids get excited to see you and you get to watch them grow. Some learn how to write their names, learn different concepts, get better at resolving conflicts, etc. It feels great when you see a child utilizing something you have taught them. I helped a girl with anger issues learn how to express herself to the other kids. The teachers have a lot of students so they don't have the chance to provide one-on-one support. This makes them very grateful for the extra help and the kids definitely enjoy and benefit from it. The training that Jumpstart provides is exceptional. The concepts and techniques I learned have been very helpful for my experiences working with kids. The training was actually superior to training I received at a daycare. Another great thing about the program is that it gets young men involved in a typically feminine occupation. Most of the teams are composed of equal numbers of men and women. This is great for the kids and the guys.
cons:
Personally, I disliked the team environment. Although I liked my team members, I just don't like working on a team. There are two team meetings a week where you do ice breakers and prepare for sessions. The team structure in the summer program was better because there are small team teaching teams of 3-4 people rather than the larger 5-15 team members during the school year. 
Another con is that some of the site managers are not very professional and are overly harsh. One site manager seemed to be making fun of me with some of the other corps members (she's no longer working there because she decided to quit). Another site manager flipped out on some of my team members, yelling at them in an unprofessional manner.

pros: the idea behind Jumpstart is very laudable and the approach that they take - trained volunteers in the classrooms - is scalable and replicable.
cons: not sure the leadership knows how to make the work of the organization actually relevant to the children and communities being served.  seems more focused on raising organization's profile and raising money than focusing on whether the work being done is meaningful, relevant, and having impact.

review_title: It was a great voluntarily work
job_title: Corps Member in New York, NY
pros: Mentoring and teaching pre-k children and receiving an educational award upon completion it great. There are set day to go in and implement early childhood curriculum and there are day you can pick and choose to help the teachers out to complete your 300 hours of service.
cons: Being that you will be working with children coming from low income families, the neighborhoods the schools are located in are not the nest, and some of the children that you will be working with have extremely bad tempers and behavior.

pros: Jumpstart is a great way for you to give back to the community. When I worked with Jumpstart I had previous experience working with kids, but not as hands on. I greatly enjoyed my kids, my team and the teach in the classroom we got paired with. This experience also opened up my eyes to a possible career in teaching.
cons: Your Jumpstart experience greatly depends on your team. If you cannot bond and respect the other members of your team, you will not have a pleasant Jumpstart experience.

pros: Jumpstart is a very well put together nationwide organization. Its goals and beliefs are great and really aim towards actually helping children.
cons: I would say that your enjoyment of working for Jumpstart really depends on which branch you work for. If your supervisors are unorganized, strict, or not passionate your time with Jumpstart will not be all that you hoped for.

pros: An amazing, life changing firsthand experience for future teachers and any other career path. Opportunity to delve into your own perspectives on education reform and advocating for young children in low income areas.
cons: Volunteer-based, so you can only get paid through work study. Time consuming--lots of trainings/workshops throughout the year.

review_title: Working for the organization is different than being a corps member
pros: Fuzzy feelings from the growth and development of college students and young children.  While the benefits package can vary, the one I had was great.
cons: Salary is very low for the region and amount/diversity of tasks being performed.  Very little support is provided from either the higher education partner or the organization itself.

pros: I made many connections and friendships, enjoyed the benefits offered, had a chance to move within the organization. Work/life balance is very good.
cons: As people say, the pay at Jumpstart is too low for many to stick around for much longer than a couple years; even if roles change, the pay increases tend to be minimal. Year after year, the organization struggles and this often affects personnel personally. Just didn't feel like a secure place to be after a while.

pros: The organization does great work in helping promote literacy and math skills in public schools! An excellent hands-on teaching experience.
cons: This is not a con, exactly, but just my personal wish that there was more that I could do. Some classrooms we went in to struggled to have basic school supplies, and I just wished more could be done to help.

pros: Schedule was pretty flexible. Welcoming and supportive team. Felt like I was making a difference in the lives of children.
cons: Don't remember having too many opportunities for networking and advancement while I was a part of the program in university. I feel like those only came once I was an alumni.

pros: Teaching and mentoring low-income preschool children through a service and social justice based organization.  This organization educates the Corps on education inequality but also citizenship and how to advocate for the communities we work with.
cons: Because you are working with low-income children, there are often language barriers between Corps Members and students as well as their parents.  JS can find more ways to support Corps Members in these instances.

pros: Although the work takes a lot of commitment, the work is fulfilling and rewarding. If you are dedicated to the work, you will experience a lot of personal and professional development.
cons: Depending on the site supervisor, the program can be a little unorganized which may take away from the otherwise rewarding experience.

pros:
Good experience in early childhood education.

Good work life balance - I believe it is doable along with schoolwork. I did not feel particularly overwhelmed by the responsibilities

Jumpstart operates at many schools. This positive review is for the supersite headed by the supervisors at The George Washington University. I know therefore that other schools may offer differing experiences.
cons: I do not want to say that everything was positive but I have nothing of memory to report, I really enjoyed my experience.

pros: There were a lot of team building activities and individual workshops but the best part was definitely working with the kids. They were a joy to be around and it was very rewarding seeing the difference in their behavior and performance throughout the program.
cons: There were too many trainings- very time consuming and difficult to keep up with during the school year. There was also a lot of paper work :/

job_title: Corp Member in New York, NY
pros: Fun people to work around, minimal base hours (balancing with full time school courseload), lots of opportunities to add more hours at home
cons: Hard to miss a session, not a lot of hours, quite a bit of training going into it, but they are really a great company to work for despite all this!

pros: Working with Jumpstart can be very tedious at times, but the personal relationships you will build can be very rewarding. You can go above or beyond, or stick to the clear and structured curriculum.
cons: Your experience is very dependent on your fellow corps members and leadership. The program has many structural errors, as it is not updated for flexibility amongst students who have varying needs.

review_title: Work-Study Corps Member and Team Leader
pros: There are so many resources available if you're truly interested in early childhood education! It's a great job that never felt like work and is incredibly rewarding.
cons: Some people are there just for the work-study paycheck or to get class credit. These people sometimes don't put forth their best work.

review_title: Less than average place to work
pros: Leave at 3 pm on Friday's
cons:
low pay

predominately white female office in a non-profit working to reduce the achievement gap for kids in poor urban communities, get ready for white savior complex.

If you look remotely close to the other minority in the office, get ready for people to confuse you with the other person all the time.

review_title: Wonderful learning experience for college students.
pros: Invaluable hands on experience teaching in functioning classrooms in the community, with a heavy emphasis on training and education it's members.
cons: After training the bulk of the work is independent, and with sites growing larger it can be difficult to feel supported by Jumpstart management.

pros:
increasing literacy amongst preschool children 
amazing site managers for support 
loved working with all the children, who were excited that we were in the classroom
cons:
Repetitive (might be because I worked all four years in college)
- especially the training at the beginning of the year. As someone who had that training 4x, I wasn't paying much attention to it the 3rd time around

review_title: Best program a college student can be apart of.
pros: Helping the community in such a substantial way was a great experience for me as a college student. The children we worked with loved the Jumpstart Session plans and always looked forward to us coming.
cons: Sometimes it can be tough to manage working 20 hours a week while being a college student but it is very rewarding.

pros: Jumpstart is a fantastic place to work. Lessons are planned with great detail, which allows teachers to maximize their effectiveness. Staff are friendly, and encourage you to work to the best of your potential. Lastly, Jumpstart provides many opportunities for teachers to learn about education and public policy issues affecting students' lives.
cons: There are none I can think of.

pros: Good emphasis on team work and solid framework of resource management with prompt and clear pay schedule, excellent for college workers.
cons: Lots of unpredictable issues due to classroom setting and individual student needs.

review_title: It is a wonderful experience working with children with your team.
job_title: Jumpstart Corps Member in New York, NY
pros:
Friendly and outgoing co-workers
Flexible and work around your schedule
Great for gaining experience
Always exciting to work with the kids
Gives you a grant to pay for college tuition or loans
cons:
It is only temporary (usually ends right after the spring semester)
Requires a great amount of patience
The pay isn't that great. (Mainly due to working few hours)

pros: I loved working with the children. We had a really great team. I enjoyed helping the teachers lower the ratio of support each child.
cons: There were no downsides. Some advice. Manage your hours you don't want to fall behind because if you do it's really hard to catch up.

job_title: Team Leader in New York, NY
pros: I love knowing that I am a part of something that is leaving such a positive impact on the lives of children across America
cons: My position is technically a volunteer position but I do get paid through my college because it counts as a work-study job. I only wish I could do this as a real job!

pros: The community outreach and the opportunity to improve literacy among underprivileged children. Also there are scholarship opportunities if you are willingly to go through all the
cons: The pay was not proportional to the time commitment and work required outside the job. Reporting hours worked was extremely frustrating.

pros: The impact that you make on these children will stay with you. It's a wonderful way to improve your community and humble yourself.
cons: Since it's an AmeriCorps program, the payment is much less than minimum wage. A great job for students on campus to make a little extra money in between classes and hopefully open their eyes to some amazing career paths.

review_title: good mission, but the company is misguided
pros:
team members
you get feedback pretty often
cons:
not transparent enough
higher ups seems not to know a lot about inner city kids and it reflects in the curriculum we are given

pros: Close knit family community. Opportunity to help low income children and their families.  Nice education award after completion of the program.
cons: Very time consuming with 5+ hours more to each weeks' work. Teams might be much to handle. Clashing personalities that need nurturing.

pros: Management is supportive. The company really wants you to succeed. The benefits package is pretty great for a non profit, two weeks paid vacation during your first year.
cons: Depending on your region, you can feel a bit disjointed from the program at a national level. The communication across regions could use some work.

pros: Teamwork and Cultural Diversity are two reasons I feel it's important to work for Jumpstart. Together as an organization you can work with other service members to really have an impact on the partner children. The experience alone coupled with the periodic trainings are valuable lessons all should learn.
cons: I cannot think of any downsides to the program/job at the moment.

job_title: Corps Member in New York, NY
pros: I worked as a corps member in Harlem. I enjoyed the working environment; my supervisor was very helpful and there seems to be lots of opportunities within the company for interested and passionate individuals.
cons: The schedule tended to be a bit erratic depending on what hours teachers were available and which day cares had available time slots.

pros: Working with kids, follow lesson plans, relationships formed with teachers and staff
cons: Shifts are in the morning so if you're not a morning person it could suck for you. You also have to be full time students

review_title: Awesome place to work for work study
pros: It is awesome to see your kids improve as you teach them the lesson plans throughout the year.
cons: Dealing with unresponsible coworkers that make it ten times harder than it should be.

job_title: Corps Member in UC Berkeley, CA
pros:
-inspires a passion for closing the gap in early childhood education that will be a part of you & your goals for the rest of your life
-relevant, in-depth trainings
-continuous no-pressure performance reviews
-bonding with your team is fun
-education award from Americorps
cons: -big time commitment, might be hard for some to balance with school and other extracurriculars

review_title: The position is fast-paced and high demanding
job_title: Site Manager in New York, NY
pros: You get to meet and work with many different types of people in different industries. Once you've gotten the hang of the basics, you have the freedom to create programming
cons: As a Site Manager, you are asked to juggle too many things as once. The administrative requirements can be overwhelming and tedious.

job_title: Jumpstart Corps Member in Chicago, IL
pros:
Gained a lot of experience working with and educating children.
Contributed to the community in a positive way.
Had a lot of fun working with children.
cons: There are no cons that I can really think of, but as a university student doing this as a part-time job, the work hours can sometimes be inconvenient.

pros: Great learning opportunity. I was able to work with a group of 3 students and develop my teamwork and communication skills. Excellent pay for Americorps and there is an additional educational scholarship.
cons: Very time consuming for a full time student. Also, the locations of the schools were a little far out from my school.

job_title: Jumpstart Corps Member in New York, NY
pros: Great opportunity to provide low-income preschool children with increasing literacy skills that will be carried on beyond kindergarten. Program consistently provides training for all members so that they can implement knowledge of reading strategies and child development knowledge to the planning of Jumpstart Sessions.
cons: Can be challenging and requires strong commitment.

pros: Great mission and purpose. Gives young people an opportunity to give back and develop basic managerial skills.
cons: Big commitment. Directly responsible for the development of young people so be prepared to invest alot of time.

pros: Getting paid to make materials is a huge plus, the curriculum has obviously been worked on a lot and perfected.
cons: Loooong training days, sometimes it feels like I'm doing things a very specific and certain way just to make Jumpstart happy.

pros: You learn a lot not only from working in the classroom with the children, but also from the trainings and working with your team.
cons: Might be a lot to handle if you are taking challenging classes and need extra time to study and do homework.

pros:
- mission driven work 
- friendly environment
- opportunities for advancement 
- connection to the community 
- gain valuable work experience
cons: Since this a fairly new position at Jumpstart through AmeriCorps, there is still a lot of room for improvement in a strategic plan for the one year position.

pros: Great management experience, lots of team collaboration, and you get to bounce off ideas from other team leaders. Our site coordinator was also amazing.
cons: I wish I had more time to dedicate to jumpstart, but it was hard when I was a full time student

pros: It is a great atmosphere, everyone gets along really well.  There is a lot of teamwork and collaboration.
cons: The salary is not enough for the amount of work that is required.  You will work 60-70 hour weeks for several months throughout the year.

pros: Evidence-based program truly able of helping children, excellent mission, friendly work environment, energetic and passionate staff, important player in national service
cons: Upper management needs to figure out direction and strategy, staff members considered expendable, lack of growth or professional development opportunities

review_title: Great way to strengthen your classroom and team management skills
pros: Very rewarding, effective way to find out if teaching is for you. Helps organizational skills.
cons: Have to have open availability. Must have at least two days per week free to volunteer plus time for meetings and trainings.

job_title: Team Leader in New York, NY
pros: You're actually making a difference in the lives of little kids; You are pretty well-equipped to teach and reflect; Can be counted towards work-study; You become an Americorps member at the end of 300 hours.
cons: Not very much compensation; a lot of prep work

job_title: Jumpstart Corps Member in Lowell, MA
pros: The experience is life changing I had so much fun in a professional and meaningful setting. It helped me improve certain skills such as working on a team, advocacy, teaching methods, and problem solving.
cons: 300 hours are hard to complete on top of school

review_title: Ignited My Passion for Early Childhood Education
pros: Working in a team of like-minded individuals to create innovative and engaging lesson plans for the children. One-on-one interaction with preschool-aged children, to give them the best chance at kindergarten readiness.
cons: Inability to continue after graduating from the university.

pros: Everyone cares so much about early childhood education. Can be self-directed in job.
cons: Non profit environment, not a lot of budget for things

review_title: Great company to make a change
pros: Work with children, manage college students, unique teaching strategies with preschoolers
cons: Lot of timesheets and paperwork, but what job doesn’t have a lot of paperwork

job_title: Corps Member in Los Angeles, CA
pros: teammates, supervisor, watching the academic/emotional/social growth of preschool children, bonding with the children, informational trainings, scholarship
cons: as a student, it can be hard some weeks that are busier than others. I had to quit to focus more on my grades, but I loved my experience!!!

pros: Meeting people who are passionate about what they do and learning a lot about yourself.
cons: Having to be able to work with others in a team setting to achieve goals together. Lots of training involved in the beginning of the year.

pros: getting to know your community and working with children is so rewarding, and Jumpstart does an awesome job of training you and supporting you throughout your assignment.
cons: It is a lot of work to prep, you have to put in the time

pros: Really fun work-study job (must like working with kids, obviously). Ideal hours for a full-time student.
cons: I had to take the bus to and from the preschool I worked at which was a downside cost and time wise. The pay overall wasn't great either.

pros: Good benefits and work-life balance. Great mission and dedicated employees!
cons: Management is constantly reorganizing and restructuring every couple of years because they've struggled with figuring out the National vs. Local structure and how to share best practices and communicate across the org.

pros: Really nice people and friendly environment and helping cute little kids!
cons: Slower pace, less efficient people, less efficiency and drive

pros:
Very good way to get involved in the community. 
Awesome opportunity to interact if you love kids.
cons: Hard to balance if you are a full-time student. Don't do it if you are not in love with teaching and helping preschool kids though.

pros: You will be helping children who are in need with learning skills get better and more involved in their education.
cons: Children can be a little difficult but just think of the huge impact you can have on their lives.

pros: The classroom experience with children was incredibly eye-opening.
cons: The schedule was not very flexible (for obvious reasons) and the curriculum was expected to be taught in a specific way - not much room to try something new.

pros:
-meaningful work, helping children set a foundation that impacts the rest of their lives
-fun to work in teams and meet children with such potential to do great things in life
cons: -no downsides that come to mind; great AmeriCorp program

pros:
It is never boring.
Some very strong staff across the network who are dedicated and passionate about early childhood and creating social change.
cons:
Financially unstable.
Disjointed leadership who are out of touch with reality.
Afraid of change.

review_title: Awesome place to volunteer with preschoolers!
pros: Work with other corp members, there is also a stipend at the end when you complete your hours.
cons:
It is mandatory to complete 300 hours of service.
It is only part-time.

review_title: It was great seeing the kids make progressively
pros: Being able to work directly with the children involved in the program and seeing them make progress over time was amazing
cons: Your experiences may vary depending on the teacher in the classroom

pros:
-good experience 
-work with children from under sourced communities 
-good learning experience
cons:
-time consuming for little compensation 
-work with a team where roles can be unfair 
-stressful at times to meet all requirements needed for session

review_title: No room for growth especially for women of color
job_title: Site Manager in New York, NY
pros: The college students and young children
cons: overworked, no room for growth, and not enough resources to support each university. Some universities have more than others. A lot of turnover.

job_title: Corps Member in Santa Ana, CA
pros: make a difference in the community(kind of)
cons: drama(immature coworkers and team leader), unorganization(inside and outside the classroom, you have to complete 300 hours for the stipend at the end(hours vary)

job_title: Corps Member in New York, NY
pros: Seeing children's eyes light up when they finally understood something, learnt a new letter, how to read and write their names. Hours and work study pay
cons: Having to travel to a site during school days.

pros: Very Professional and Meaningful work to help underprivileged children to not left behind before they got to elementary schools.
cons: The salary is low, and the work can sometimes be disorganized.

review_title: Loved it, overall great mentoring experience.
pros: Motivate children from SES families to gain interest in reading.
cons: You have to be willing to put in the work. A lot of out of "office" prepping and training courses.

review_title: It was a great job, loved the children
pros: great children, you really see sometimes how you can make a difference in a childs life, very fun
cons: leadership may not always be up to par (team leader)

pros: If you want to go into teaching or childcare, it's good experience for you.
cons: Jumpstart can be a little unorganized when the partner schools are unorganized, which happens more often than you'd think.

pros: Meet a lot of great people and have a blast while making an impact in many children's lives
cons: If you work in the morning it can be gruesome waking up at times

pros: Children improving and overall are happy. The teachers are supportive. You receive a Stipend.
cons: Make sure you take advantage of this opportunity when you do not have an already hectic schedule.

review_title: Excellent, flexible experience while in school
pros: Great experience while in school. I was able to learn new skills while serve in preschools my community.
cons: Pay and education award is a challenge while paying for school.

pros: Great relationships built with the kids, teamwork experience, great thing to put on a resume.
cons: Transportantion, at least for me had to be paid out of pocket. Lot of time invested.

pros: So much fun to work with the kids
cons: Poorly organized institutionally where I was, but it is a national non profit so I believe it completely depends on where you are.

review_title: It's a good pay for college students.
pros: Good environment, and good opportunity to gain experience to pursue a career in education.
cons: If you get on the bad side of the higher authority, you might be pushed out.

pros: Working for jumpstart was very fulfilling
cons: It was very time consuming and required some work to be done at home.

pros: Kids are fun and a good environment. Helping others.
cons: Managing lots of people can be overwhelming if you are not up to it.

pros: Collaborative team! Really appreciated the support I received from staff on site and the leadership at other sites!
cons: More training needed to ensure success of corps members within the organization.

pros: Plenty of training and support.  Rewarding work.  Challenging.  Purposeful
cons: Still growing on the national scale.  Trainings can get to be redundant.  Too much reflection at times.

pros: the kids are amazing...you became very attentive to the smaller details in life
cons: time consuming, the schedule is very hectic and you spend most days planning for session

pros: You work with a team filled with individuals who are passionate about early childhood education. Gain access to Jumpstart's connections.
cons: The amount of work can be overwhelming during a busy week.

pros: Being able to collaborate with co-workers at different sites makes the position better.
cons: The pay is not enough for the expected work. There is a good deal of miscommunication from top to bottom.

pros: Interning at Jumpstart was enjoyable, the office environment was casual, and everyone was friendly.
cons: The internship was unpaid which was a major downfall. At least minimum wage would have been appreciated.

pros: leadership opportunities, flexible schedule, training in the beginning of the year, continuous support from site managers and team members
cons: Sites can be a bit far away, weekend trainings

pros: Great for those you guys that enjoy working with kids. Everything is mostly straightforward, exactly as you expect. It feels like volunteer work
cons: Some children may be ill tempered

pros: Best Site Supervisor, The Privilege to Gain Skills Applicable for many Careers, Cohort of Like-Minded Individuals who encourage Greatness
cons: I wasn't able to continue my work with Jumpstart after graduation.

pros: Great organizational purpose, can really see changes/effects in children you work with
cons: Did not fully agree with a lot of the specific company choices in terms of regulations and teaching practices

job_title: Community Engagement Coordinator in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
-Great benefits for staff/employee
-2 weeks paid vacation in December apart from PTO and Sick time
-Very flexible with work schedule
-Able to telecommute on some days
cons: -Restructuring often makes it difficult to adjust

review_title: It's great seeing the effects or your work
job_title: Jumpstart Corps Member in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Team Building, seeing that the work you do is making a difference in children's lives.
cons: Low Pay for a work study university student.

job_title: Jumpstart Corps Member in Chicago, IL
pros:
1) Meaningful Mission
2) Good training opportunities
3) Good work/life balance
4) Structured Lesson plans
cons:
1) Team Leaders were a hit or miss
2) Repetitive, sometimes mundane tasks
3) Some classroom teachers are unhelpful

pros: Great Staff. Great Experience. Very Rewarding.
cons: No real cons. Only con I can think of is that it was only part time.

review_title: A wonderful, enlightening experience working with children.
pros: Learn communication skills and patience when dealing with children.
cons: Since most children are from low income neighborhoods, language barriers and behavioral issues can arise.

job_title: Jumpstart Corps Member in Jamaica, NY
pros: The kids are amazing, absolutely love working with them
cons: Because we started a bit late, it's a little difficult to finish all 300 hrs but it's doable
